blog_data.sub_text: Taking Logistics to the next level
blog_data.description: 'Last Friday during the family lunch, my five-year old suddenly remembered that he hasn’t enjoyed eating his favourite “Hajmola” for a long time'......

full_blog_content.desc: Last Friday during the family lunch,my five-year old suddenly remembered that he hasn’t enjoyed eating his favourite “Hajmola” for a long time. While we were thinking about how to get him a small bottle of Hajmola, he quickly mentioned:” Mumma, order it from Amazon Prime”. The Hajmola was ordered and received by night on the same day. We were astonished at the speed of delivery of such a small item at zero delivery charge.

Experiences like this are delightful for customers. They get us to think of how this omnichannel giant, Amazon, has such a supercharged supply chain. E-commerce is growing at an unprecedented rate all across the world. The supply chain remains the online businesses’ best means of providing customer satisfaction and earn brand loyalty. It also merits attention as to how these ecommerce platforms are fulfilling such quick deliveries, what hurdles they have to overcome, and what are the future opportunities that can be tapped to improve efficiency and increase profitability. One such opportunity which is going to be a game-changer for the internet era is “On-Demand Warehousing”.

We all realize today that in this digital age, ready access to goods & services is vital. I don’t drive; however, I get an Uber on-demand to pick my son from school. It is not possible to buy all storybooks for my son so I take books on demand from a library and there are many such examples. The term on-demand implies getting access to goods and services as and when required.

On-demand Warehousing is the ability to get warehousing services as per the business requirement. It gives retailers and brands a scalable, flexible warehousing solution. It relies on a marketplace model and transactional pricing so that retailers and brands can expand and contract their networks as needed. Its three principal components are storage, fulfilment, and last mile delivery. This implies if a company has taken on-demand warehousing facility they would be entitled to getting space for storage, transportation, and should they choose, also a team for delivering till the doorstep of the customer. What makes the model so exciting is its flexible nature, where the business owners can scale up to meet the peak demand and scale down when the demand reverts to normal levels. The business owners can optimize production and inventory levels thus an on-demand warehousing model helps the seller to keep the cost under control and meet the customers’ expectations at the same time.
In this blog, we would first understand how on-demand warehousing works and then explore how this new idea is helping companies to solve their biggest supply chain challenges.
**How On Demand Warehousing Works:**

As per the business requirement, companies can choose warehouses at different locations from an On-Demand Warehouse provider like Hubshub. They can pay for the warehouse space, fulfilment and retail distribution required presently. Companies also have access to real-time inventory at each warehouse, and an option to scale up or down depending on business needs. Ancillary functions like redistribution, re packaging and warehouse optimization are also available as additional options.
**How On-Demand Warehousing helps companies to solve biggest supply chain challenges:**

● Adapting to sudden demand changes: It is amazing how fast the demand can change but can the supply chain keep up to the rapid changes? As much as the companies use Artificial Intelligence, Demand projection tools to forecast demand and plan ahead, supply chain disruptions are inevitable. This is where on-demand warehousing comes in and gives businesses a short-term solution for their storage options, fulfilment and retail distribution. The sellers can scale up or down at a short notice leading to better resource utilization. They manage to be efficient and profitable during shifts in demand and supply.

● Improving delivery times: Buyers are spoilt for choice & expect the retailers to deliver the goods as soon as possible. In fact, while ordering for daily supplies from Amazon, I was amazed to see an option “Amazon Fresh”. It promised delivery on the same day as ordering. It is no secret today that buying decisions are governed by delivery speed. We all check the delivery date before placing an order. On-demand warehousing helps retailers to choose a warehouse closer to the end user, hence increasing the speed of delivery, decreasing the last mile delivery cost and most importantly enhancing the customer experience.

● Handling Seasonal variations: Some businesses are seasonal in nature like sellers of blankets and woollens. Pre-winter Retail shops are full of customers buying different sizes of woollens, online portals are full of options of different brands, some brands even set up pop-up shops to improve visibility. Last winter, I visited a leading woollen brand store multiple times looking for a particular size and colour of sweater. but every time I got the same reply “Madam, we are out of stock for your requirement”. This is where on demand warehousing can help the retailer to add warehouses to better handle inventory by supporting retail stores and ecommerce platforms during the seasonal requirements.

● Providing flexibility: On demand warehousing helps brands to plan for new initiatives without affecting their current operations. It gives brands an opportunity to test new strategies and enter new markets without any fixed costs or long-term contracts. A retailer can introduce a product and add a fulfilment centre to facilitate sales. if the product doesn’t work, the option of scaling back without affecting the year-round operations always exists while remaining cost efficient. Similarly, a company can also optimise on their cost per unit by planning storage with on demand warehousing. They can only store a minimum level of inventory as per their monthly sales and scale up as required.

● Benefiting businesses with real time inventory visibility and detailed reporting: This is my very recent experience with an online clothing retailer. I ordered two t-shirts for my five-year-old. The order was accepted and the delivery was scheduled for a given date. However, closer to the delivery date, my order was cancelled and I was given a coupon as a goodwill gesture. This is an example of supply chain mismanagement, wherein, the retailer has already sold the available inventory, however, the stock is not updated real time and hence resulted in a poor customer experience. On demand warehousing helps retailers to see their real time inventory across locations. Detailed reporting of sales and in stock inventory helps the companies to replenish in time as well as stack away unused inventory to optimise cost.

With economic uncertainties lingering longer than expected, logistics and supply chain optimization is one of the top priorities for businesses. The required speed of service has made it important for organizations to reconfigure supply chains and find space in tier-2/ tier-3 cities as reported in this Economic Times’ article.

However, currently searching for a warehouse traditionally ,is a nightmare as regular brokers have limited inventory and their own nuances. Considering this, most companies are stockpiling as a cautionary measure. If one does happen to find a broker who can help you lease out the required space, the terms and pricing of the lease could act as a major deterrent. Hence, today the need for on-demand warehousing is like never before. It simplifies and expedites the search process and provides maximum flexibility with minimum hassles.

blog_data.sub_text: A key concern in growing Indian logistics market
blog_data.description: 'Many of us read about the recent burglary incident where Samsung phone parts worth ₹ 80 Lakhs were stolen from a warehouse in Noida'......
blog_data.author: Nupur Singh

full_blog_content.desc: Many of us read about the recent burglary incident where [Samsung phone parts worth ₹ 80 Lakhs](https://www.livemint.com/companies/news/noida-samsung-phone-parts-worth-rs-80-lakh-stolen-from-warehouse-4-arrested-11595209978733.html) were stolen from a warehouse in Noida. Prior to that, there was a story on [a massive fire at a medical equipment warehouse in Delhi.](https://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi-news/major-fire-in-west-delhi-warehouse-official/story-fUiIs8mmcFM26iTBMne0dJ.html) Unfortunately, inventory loss has grown at a rapid pace along with the dramatic growth of Indian Logistics Market in the past few years. [As per BSI and TT club report, India accounted for 64% of Asia’s cargo theft in 2019.](https://www.itln.in/india-accounts-for-64-of-asias-cargo-theft-in-2019-bsi-tt-club-report-logistics) A pertinent question for warehouse owners & users today is how to prevent or minimise inventory loss. The gravity of this pilferage is much more than simple inventory loss. The loss of brand value and brand loyalty due to unavailability of product in the right quantity at the right time can be irreparable.

[As per GlobeNewsWire.com, Logistics market in India is forecasted to grow at a CAGR of 10.5](https://www.globenewswire.com/news-release/2020/04/01/2009812/0/en/India-s-Logistics-Market-2020-Research-Report.html) percent between2019-2025. Warehousing is a vital part of the logistics network. Operations across industries like E-commerce, retail, FMCG, third-party logistics, cold storage, pharma and manufacturing include the use of warehouses. In fact, the warehousing sector is expected to add 40 million square feet of space across the top 8 Indian cities, a recent survey said. While the exponential growth of the warehousing sector has made it easier for companies to deliver goods to customers on time, it has also exposed volumes of inventory to multiple potential risks. Security and Loss prevention has become one of the major concerns of warehouses today. As has been the experience of warehouse users, taking an insurance policy to deleverage this risk is not the only solution.

In this blog, we are going to talk about security features that a warehouse should have to reduce the critical risks and overcome inventory loss. If you are a company, you can prepare your security systems checklist for choosing a warehouse and warehouses can upgrade themselves, if any of the below features are missing. The warehouse operations need to focus on 3 key elements under each category described below: People, Process and Technology.
**Fire & Floods:**
Warehouses are mostly packed with goods and even a small fire can lead to extensive product damage and employee injury. The following three ways can help reduce warehouse fire risk.

1. Install Fire Detection and Suppression Systems like smoke alarm, fire alarm, fire extinguishers, fire doors, hazardous gas detection systems. All these systems need to be checked regularly & maintained for good working conditions as per the local laws and industry best practices.

2. Fire Safety Drill should be practised regularly and all evacuation procedures should be well documented. It should be a part of induction of all new employees and fire safety maps should be available behind all exit doors. Employees should be trained to be vigilant in identifying and reporting fire hazards.

3. Install “Warehouse Security Cameras”. Just installing the cameras will not do the magic. An operator is required to monitor the cameras at all times, who can report in case of fire in any section of the warehouse. Quick reporting can help in containing the fire. Hence reducing loss of valuable inventory and minimizing employee injury.

4. In flood prone areas, all external doors should have guards to prevent water from seeping in. Paper records should be stored at upper level. And, warehouses should invest in heavy duty high racks to store heavy stock at a height. All electrical installations should be far above the ground level to prevent water going into the electrical systems.
**Theft:**

Warehouses are susceptible to burglary, considering the high volume and in come cases  high value inventory. As BSI and TT club report mentions, companies in India are facing a serious issue of theft. Warehouses can strengthen security to reduce incidents of theft. Below are the few ways to bolster the warehouse security system

**1.** Access Control System:  Only authorized personnel with photo id or access cards can enter the warehouse. Employees have to swipe their card at the building entrance to gain access. This system can give complete information on entry and exit timings of employees on a daily basis. It can also be used to limit access of employees to specific areas in the warehouse. Integrating the access control technology with photo identification and biometrics or retina scan can ensure that cards are used only by authorized personnel.

**2.** High Definition Video Surveillance Cameras should be installed at all entrance points and all sensitive interior areas to record activity at all times. This camera should be monitored 24/7 by security personnel as well.
**3. Facility Structure:**
● Warehouses should have a boundary wall with anti- climb spikes.
● The gates of the exterior yard should always be manned and locked allowing entry only to authorised personnel and vehicles.
● Provide audible alarms at all doors, when the warehouse is closed and all emergency exit doors when it is open.
● All areas of the warehouse should have enough lighting for people to feel safe and to deter thieves.
**4. Visitor Registers & Triggered emails:**
● All visitors should sign in the visitor register at the warehouse entrance and should be allotted a visitor pass. The staff must be trained to adhere to this policy all the time.
● Visitors should be always accompanied by an employee
● Warehouse security head should get triggered emails upon entry and exit of each visitor.
**5. Signs:** Post signs that warn and deter unauthorised personnel like” This warehouse is under CCTV surveillance at all times” preferably in the regional language as well.

**6. Employee Background Checks:** Employees are an internal threat to the warehouse business. Recently, I read a news article where a [former employee was involved in the warehouse robbery case in Gurugram.](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/gurgaon/three-held-for-amazon-warehouse-theft-in-gurugram/articleshow/74095443.cms) To avoid such scenarios warehouses need to do a thorough background check before hiring. You can also set up a reporting system where any employee can inform the manager about a co-worker stealing from the warehouse or on suspicious events. Such reports can be kept anonymous to avoid employee rivalry while maintaining an open reporting culture.
**Employee Safety:**
● All employees should be given job and equipment training upon joining and at regular intervals as refreshers.
● All areas should be well lit, and inventory should be arranged at all times to prevent slips, trips and falls.
● Equipment should be checked regularly to ensure it is in good working condition.

● Manual lifting can be hazardous for employee’s health and can lead to injury too. Hence, lifting equipment can be used instead to avoid repetitive strain on labourers. Correct lifting techniques should be taught to the workers handling heavy lift regularly.
**Stock Damage:**
● Use correct machinery and tools for each task.
● Train employees in handling all types of materials.
● All materials should be handled with care, especially fragile items. Limit any unessential movement.

● Keep items stocked by weight and shape. If possible, keep heavier items near the front of the warehouse, on lower shelves, so items won’t need to be handled and moved around as much as lighter items, which can be stored in the back of the warehouse on higher shelves.
● Use smart racking solutions like support bars, step beams, aisle shields.
● Use of warehouse shelf containers like metal storage containers, bins, boxes, collapsible containers.
● Use of safety wraps on pallets on racks and stretch wraps during transportation to keep the goods in place.
**Equipment Failure:**
● Routine Maintenance of all equipment should be done.
● Only trained employees to use equipment and proper procedure must be followed.
● All security systems like CCTV cameras, swipe machines, alarm systems to be checked at regular intervals to see they are in good working condition.
● Identify critical security equipment and keep some spares handy toa count for failures.
**Handling Hazardous Substances:**
● Segregate, label and store all hazardous substances correctly.
● Ensure standard operating procedures include proper labelling, is documented and followed for storage, dispense and disposal.
● Routine safety assessment is to be done in accordance to the government’s rules and regulations for handling hazardous substances.
● Have an emergency action plan in place and employees trained to execute it.

As warehouses and their stocks are extremely valuable, every effort should be made to protect the assets against the above-mentioned hazards. However, such incidents can happen even after taking utmost precautions, so the warehouse must have comprehensive insurance for building as well as contents that it stores. Insurance should include any damages arising from storage of all possible varieties of goods .

I’ll conclude with a headline from a recent article [“ Amazon deploys thermal cameras at warehouses to scan for feverish workers”.](https://in.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-amazon-com-cameras-ex/exclusive-amazon-deploys-thermal-cameras-at-warehouses-to-scan-for-fevers-faster-idINKBN2200HZ) This brings forth the new normal of current times- Coping with Covid-19. Warehouses are always a constant hub of activity with people moving in and out of the premises and hence highly prone to this risk. While one way to mitigate risk is to deploy thermal cameras, it is also important to train employees on social distancing, wearing masks always and basic hygienic practices like frequent washing and sanitising hands properly.

blog_data.description: Globalization emerged as the most talked-about business phenomenon over the past several decades
blog_data.author: Nupur Singh

full_blog_content.desc: Globalization emerged as the most talked-about business phenomenon over the past several decades, as one of the greatest forces in spreading new technologies and providing new economic opportunities in both developed and developing economies. Across industries, companies procured raw materials from Country A, set up manufacturing units in Country B and sold the finished product worldwide.  Companies had high-flying executives who travelled across the world to meet prospective customers, suppliers and partners, closing lucrative deals for their firms. Business in the globalised economy heralded the use of modern supply chain practices like off-shore manufacturing to improve cost structures.

Then came 2020 -  In January, the news of Covid-19 started to trickle out of China and by March, the whole world was reeling from the effects of the pandemic. A pandemic of this magnitude caught companies across industries off-guard and disrupted supply chains across the world, with businesses being affected on both the demand and supply fronts. A market-leading car manufacturer had to shut down seven of its factories in Korea due to qualified vendors’ inability to deliver components for their vehicles’ production. These suppliers were located within Hubei province, where the local Government had implemented a total lockdown during the Covid outbreak. On the demand front, leading retailers had to shut down stores to prevent the spread of the virus. The uncertainty instilled a sense of fear into the hearts and minds of consumers. As a result, while demand for non- essential goods plummeted, the demand for essentials saw a sudden surge as people prepared for the worst. Closer home, the omni channel giant, Amazon suspended delivery of all non-essential items, a sign of the severity of the situation.

The Covid-19 pandemic has tested the supply chain more severely than any other event in recent history. This unpredictable and unprecedented pandemic wave has shifted the focus from globalisation to 'Resilience', which signifies a state of bouncing back. Companies that are braving the pandemic, having endured the worst of times the human race has seen in recent history, need to be resilient to survive and bounce back to return eventually to their earlier glory.  In these troubled times, companies have realised that flexibility, the means to choose from different options, is everything. To become resilient, companies are now more likely to have multiple suppliers, multi-shore manufacturing units and higher inventories placed closer to the consumers to guard against potential shortages and reduce the risk of supply chain disruption.
In this blog, we are going to talk about the contribution of on-demand warehousing in helping companies build a resilient supply chain to recover from this situation.

In pre-Covid-19 times, supply chain managers kept inventory levels low to drive efficiency. However, in times of crisis like the one we are facing now, the drive for efficiency leaves companies with huge inventory shortages. Even if firms have sufficient inventory in warehouses, typically located in cities’ peripheral areas and far from the larger customer base, getting them to their distribution and retail partners has become a huge challenge.

Today, fast delivery is a crucial requirement; hence, companies now need more warehousing space within the city limits to service their consumers. However, adding new warehouses to your distribution network is not easy. It requires multi-year contracts and huge investments, and in the current scenario of demand and supply uncertainties, it is difficult for companies to make long-term distribution decisions.

Fortunately, 'On-Demand Warehousing' exists. A recent report highlighted how the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic is drawing interest in on-demand warehousing by retailers. On-Demand warehousing makes it easy for companies to add or remove warehouses from their network. Companies pay for the capacity and services they use. There are no long-term contracts and no huge one-time investments. All the warehouses in the network share the same software and reporting platform. This makes it easier for companies to understand their raw material or finished product stockpiling and stock replenishment requirement.
To delve further into this, let us see why this new sector is set to boom amid the pandemic fall-out and how it is becoming one of the key pillars in helping companies build a resilient supply chain.

**1.** Dispersion is the new mantra: Today, the concept of having consolidated warehouses at a single location is being challenged. Supply Chain managers have realised from this experience that, if the warehouse location is locked down due to any event in the future, their entire distribution and manufacturing network could be destabilized. With companies on the lookout for multiple warehouses spread across different locations, on-demand warehousing emerges as the best available option for them.

**2.** Stockpiling vs Lean Inventory: In 2019, companies all over the globe grew leaner by reducing their inventory carrying cost and transportation spending. However, when the lockdown was suddenly implemented, this trend brought its own issues for manufacturing and supply chains. In India, production of many pharmaceutical products came to a halt as China, the supplier for active pharmaceutical ingredients that are key ingredients for manufacturing pharma products, was locked down. This is a perfect example of why, going forward,  companies will not only look for suppliers from multiple regions, but also prefer to keep higher levels of inventories in warehouses closer to the manufacturing units to avoid supply chain disruption. Additionally, companies will try to have backup storage options in different cities to mitigate the risk of inventory shortage if one city is affected by any hyperlocal event in the future.

**3.** Accelerated Adoption of E-Commerce:  As per a report by Economic Times, online grocers in India, like Big Basket and Grofers have seen the demand for groceries and essentials surge by 3-5x. Even after the lockdown has been lifted and the 'Unlock' phase has begun, people are avoiding going to super markets from the fear of contracting Covid-19. The convenience of ordering both essential and non-essential items online at competitive rates has strengthened the market share of ecommerce retailers, and will only accelerate the growth of on-demand warehousing.

**4.** Decentralised Demand: With WFH becoming the New Normal now, and even a permanent system in some companies, a significant portion of the workforce is shifting base to Tier 2 & Tier 3 cities. With offices looking to move base to these places too, these locations are set to becoming the new sought-after warehousing destinations.

**5.** Agri Products Warehousing:  Scarcity of Agricultural warehousing space has become one of the biggest drivers for warehousing growth. The government, on its part, has also come up with incentive schemes for setting up agro-based warehouses.

Shift of manufacturing units: Post the pandemic, many leading companies across the globe are planning to shift their manufacturing base out of China. Companies have realised that dependence on one region or one country for their supply or manufacturing needs is not a viable option and can unsettle their supply chain again in the future. This shift in manufacturing units will bring in new opportunities for many other developing nations and give impetus to warehousing services in these regions as well.
To conclude, Companies have learned first-hand the importance of these aspects from the biggest supply chain disruption in recent history:
**a.** Building Regional Supply Chains
**b.** Balancing Efficiency and Resilience.
**c.** Leaning on Technology

**d.** When companies work towards building a resilient supply chain, they would need flexible plans and systems. Hence, 'On-Demand Warehousing' is emerging as one of the most important cogs in the wheel of building a pandemic-proof & resilient supply chain.
